Hi Corey, thanks for joining the conversation. Can you mock this up and show the community what you had in mind? Here's some tips to get your started - http://ideo.pn/pr0t0type. Perhaps somethings to consider are:- How would we dispose of this, would the whole bucket me thrown away?- What kind of sanitization mechanisms would you use if the bucket was to be kept?- How can we protect the caregivers disposing of this waste, since the patients are unlikely to be the ones doing this?- How can we easily distribute these kits to households that need them?We're looking forward to seeing this idea grow!

Hey Debra, i'm working on a prototype its dodgy but the idea is all there ,basically its a mop like bucket and once it had been filled i'm guessing every 2-3 days , 1 per person , someone would come and pick it up dispose of properly, through quarantining , there would need to be a registered system so that its monitored and infected patients  could be safely segregated ,This is a disposable unit that would be replaced, there would be a air locked seal with a handle so its easily transported , there would be need for bucket stations in infected areas so its freely available to the public , this would be the same idea for  the return of the buckets,caregivers would still need to wear (PPE's) however cross contamination would far be less likely due to its locking system

Don't get me wrong with the pictures i'm hoping if u guys put something together it will b fifty times the quality  i dont have any meterials and i needed a picture to get u guys thinking its relatively easy thinking ill be posting a diagram of what the end product will look like

Portal-loo like system that entails toiletry packages for the infected containing a splash proof bucket with rubber tongue's inside with a rim like toilet seat for comfortability ,the packages would include 1 splash proof bucket, sufficient toilet roll,disinfectant an a air lockd lid with handle for easy disposibility 

it will work becuase its cheap easily desposible and it will help with cross contamination between infected patiants and non infected patiants through safe disposal of fecal and urinal matter
